content: <?xml version="1.0"?> <metadata><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Solid Waste and Emergency Response, Center for Program Analysis</origin><pubdate>20091117</pubdate><title>RE-Powering Screening Shapefile</title><geoform>vector digital data</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Washington, DC</pubplace><publish>U.S. EPA Office of Solid Waste and Emergency Response (OSWER)</publish></pubinfo><onlink>http://www.epa.gov/renewableenergyland/maps/RE-Powering_Screening_shapefile.zip</onlink><onlink>http://www.epa.gov/renewableenergyland/rd_mapping_tool.htm</onlink></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Office of Solid Waste and Emergency Response (OSWER) Center for Program Analysis (CPA) initiated the RE-Powering America\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Land Initiative to demonstrate the enormous potential that contaminated lands, landfills, and mine sites provide for developing renewable energy in the United States. EPA developed national level site screening criteria in partnership with the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) for wind, solar, biomass, and geothermal facilities. While the screening criteria demonstrate the potential to reuse contaminated land for renewable energy facilities, the criteria and data are neither designed to identify the best sites for developing renewable energy nor all-inclusive. Therefore, more detailed, site-specific analysis is necessary to identify or prioritize the best sites for developing renewable energy facilities based on the technical and economic potential.  Please note that these sites were only pre-screened for renewable energy potential. The sites were not evaluated for land use constraints or current on the ground conditions. Additional research and site-specific analysis are needed to verify viability for renewable energy potential at a given site. </abstract><purpose>The federal- and state-tracked sites included in this screening represent a subset of nationwide contaminated lands, landfills, and mine sites. RE-Powering screened sites currently tracked through EPA remediation and grant programs, as well as sites tracked by five state agencies selected as a pilot expansion of this tool. Additional sites are tracked at the state and local level. </purpose><supplinf>More information, including data guidelines, a Google Earth interactive map, static maps, and fact sheets on incentives can be found at http://www.epa.gov/renewableenergyland/</supplinf></descript><timeperd><current>Current as of publication</current><timeinfo><sngdate><caldate>201307</caldate></sngdate></timeinfo></timeperd><status><progress>Complete</progress><update>As The information on the facilities and sites, including the locations, has been gathered from a number of sources. While EPA subjects the data to Quality Assurance (QA) procedures, the Agency cannot vouch for the reliability of all the data. Users of the data (or any portion thereof) may wish to verify its accuracy before use.  Data were collected using methods that have unknown accuracy (EPA National Geospatial Data Policy [NGDP] Accuracy Tier 10). For more information, please see EPA's NGDP at http://epa.gov/geospatial/policies.html)</horizpar></horizpa></posacc><lineage><procstep><procdate>2012</procdate><procdesc>Compiled data from EPA databases (CERCLIS, ACRES, RCRA CA Inventory, and LMOP database) and state sources (CA, NJ, NY, OR, HI, VA, WV, PA), plotted points and generated shapefile of points.</procdesc></procstep><procstep><procdate>2013</procdate><procdesc>Joined EPA and state tracked sites to NREL Biomass, Solar (DNI and LATILT), and Wind Data to obtain resource information for obtain distance in miles from this infrastructure. </procdesc></procstep><procstep><procdate>2013</procdate><procdesc>Joined EPA and state tracked sites to Southern Methodist University and USGS features</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>CANDLFG</attrlabl><attrdef>Landfill is accepting waste or has been closed for five years or less, has at least one million tons of waste, and does not have an operational or under-construction landfill gas (LFG) energy project; can also be designated based on actual interest by the site. Landfills can have more than one LFG energy project record.</attrdef><attrdefs>EPA</attrdefs><attrdomv><udom>Information about features</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>POTLFG</attrlabl><attrdef>Landfill does not meet the candidate definition, whether because of complete or incomplete data. However, the landfill could have LFG energy project potential based on site-specific needs or if data were complete.  Landfills can have more than one LFG energy project record.</attrdef><attrdefs>EPA</attrdefs><attrdomv><udom>Information about features</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>OPLFG</attrlabl><attrdef>The landfill gas energy project is commercially operational.  Landfills can have more than one LFG energy project record. For these sites, there may be potential to leverage LFG infrastructure for co-generation with renewable energy source.</attrdef><attrdefs>EPA</attrdefs><attrdomv><udom>Information about features</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>CONLFG</attrlabl><attrdef>The landfill gas energy project is under construction.  Landfills can have more than one LFG energy project record. For these sites, there may be potential to leverage LFG infrastructure for co-generation with renewable energy source.</attrdef><attrdefs>EPA</attrdefs><attrdomv><udom>Information about features</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>SDLFG</attrlabl><attrdef>The landfill gas energy project has ceased operation.  Landfills can have more than one LFG energy project record. For these sites, there may be potential to leverage LFG infrastructure for new development with renewable energy source.</attrdef><attrdefs>EPA</attrdefs><attrdomv><udom>Information about canola, dry edible beans, dry edible peas, peanuts, potatoes, safflower, sunflower, sugarcane, and flaxseed</attrdef><attrdefs>EPA, NREL</attrdefs><attrdomv><udom>Information about features</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>URBANAREA</attrlabl><attrdef>Indicates the closest "Urban Area" as defined by US Census Bureau. In general, this territory consists of areas of high population density and urban land use resulting in a representation of the "urban footprint." There are two types of urban areas: urbanized areas (UAs) that contain 50,000 or more people and urban clusters (UCs) that contain at least 2,500 people, but fewer than 50,000 people (except in the U.S. Virgin Islands and Guam which each contain urban clusters with populations greater than 50,000).</attrdef><attrdefs>EPA, Census</attrdefs><attrdomv><udom>Information about features</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>UAPOP</attrlabl><attrdef>Population of closest Urban Area</attrdef><attrdefs>EPA, Census</attrdefs><attrdomv><udom>Information about features</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>DISTUA</attrlabl><attrdef>Distance in miles to closest Urban Area</attrdef><attrdefs>EPA, Census</attrdefs><attrdomv><udom>Information about features</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>BIOREFIN</attrlabl><attrdef>Maximum of two potential feedstock types in metric tons/year, used to determine biorefinery siting potential, includes either (1) crops; or (2) cumulative residues from forests, primary and secondary mills, and urban wood waste.</attrdef><attrdefs>EPA, NREL</attrdefs><attrdomv><udom>Information about features</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>Forest</attrlabl><attrdef>Forest residues (dry metric tons/year), includes logging residues and other removable material left after carrying out features</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>Landfill</attrlabl><attrdef>Methane emissions from landfills (metric tons/year)</attrdef><attrdefs>EPA, NREL</attrdefs><attrdomv><udom>Information
